or next I've got salting agent salting agent this 
is fun I love this this is do we know we know what

this is fish sauce it's my favorite ingredients 
in the kitchen it doesn't smell so good but it

tastes really good it acts a nice not only does 
it season the dish it has umami like savoriness

to your dish without the need of msg we use this 
in almost everything it's a problem if you are a

vegetarian so when you go to a Thai restaurant 
might be something you want to add to choose oh

we don't use salt rarely the only time we do use 
salt is in dessert because this would not be good

and dessert and sometimes we use salt if we don't 
want the liquid nature of this so making curry

paste we don't want to add any liquid to it so 
we use salt sometimes we use salt in combination

with fish sauce because if you're making something 
that's a little bit milder flavored and you don't

want the fishiness to overpower it use it in 
combination and you tone it down a little bit

okay so a good bottle of fish sauce fish sauce 
ages unlike a bottle of wine ages in a bad way

once you open it it'll get darker and more opaque 
and when that happens it turns from good fishy to

bad fishing okay a fresh bottle of fish sauce 
should be reddish brown and clear enough that

you should be able to see stuff in the other side 
of the room if it's dark and opaque it's old so

to make you technically don't have to store this 
in the fridge but if you do it will make it last

longer make sure the cap is tightly sealed it'll 
last you longer my mom actually no longer buys big

bottles you only buys little ones then she doesn't 
have to worry about it going going off too much

these are that's fish sauce other salting agent 
that we use a lot is soy sauce and oyster sauce

oyster sauce any brand will do this is a Thai 
brand but any any of them will work soy sauce

on the other hand Thai soy sauce is different from 
Chinese Japanese soy sauce quite dramatically it's

lighter in color and the fragrance is different 
so you can get your hand on a bottle of these

it's really cheap everything here is cheap it'll 
make a difference in a lot of your dishes now soy

sauce and oyster sauce is a Chinese influence 
on Thai cuisine the Chinese gave out a lot of

things including these as well as the art of stir 
frying so naturally we use these most often in

stir-fry dishes there's other kinds of soy sauces 
that we use but as part of the basic pantry just

worry about these two you can come up and take a 
look I'm not going to talk about all of these but

if you're interested to see what else I have all 
this comes from my house you can come up later on

and taste them so that's our salt mix our acids 
type is een does not use vinegar in cooking we

use vinegar only for pickling and for tableside 
seasoning and things like that but when we cook

we use fruits fruit acids two major sources lime 
juice and tamarind juice lime juice we use a lot

in cold applications and in soups although you're 
adding this to soup you want to make sure the

soup is done turn it off then at the lime if you 
cook lime juice or lemon juice and this applies

all across all cuisines you lose that refreshing 
citrusy flavor that lime is good for so you don't

want to cook it that's why we use this a lot in 
our salads and dips tamarind on the other hand

you can use in hot and cold application it's a 
major ingredient in cut type the the acidity of

tamarind is a little bit not a sharpest lime it's 
got a little bit of a sweetness that rounds it off

it's also thicker so it'll give body and color 
to whatever dish you're making now Tamron comes

from this this is tamarind fruit looks like dry 
food but it's not dried this is you know the way

it is sometimes you can buy them already made in 
a juice it's usually called concentrate I think

but sometimes you see this block of pulp I think 
you've seen this and basically you just have to

turn this into juice and I have a to torture fruit 
or a video on my website on how to do that so if

you're interested you can go ahead and look that 
up all right so that's our acids next our sweets

we use two different types of sugar granulated 
white sugar and palm sugar now originally we

only use palm sugar because it was all we had 
granulated sugar came into Thailand later and

it became popular because it's convenient I mean 
this is easy to use this is this is not so easy to

use but this doesn't have the beautiful caramel 
flavor that this contains so if you can cook

with palm sugar what you do is you can take it 
and chop it with a knife like you would shave a

block of chocolate or I pound it in my mortar and 
pestle and it just breaks into chunks like this I

can eat it like candy you're more than welcome 
to come and eat this afterwards obviously this

needs heat and liquid to dissolve so in cold 
application I make a palm sugar Sara just cook

down some sugar with some water and keep it in a 
bottle like this so it's convenient when I go to

use it in the salad and things like that I don't 
have to worry about dissolving it or anything

but what sugar to use my rule of thumb is if 
the sugar plays a major role in the dish or

if the dish is delicate flavor use palm sugar 
because you will benefit from it but if a dish

is really strong flavored and the sugar is only 
a teaspoon here and there don't need to worry

about it granulated sugar will work just fine 
all right so that's our sweet what's my next

one others the others category bless you coconut 
milk coconut milk in Thai cuisine is used in the

same way that milk and dairy and cream are used 
in Western cuisine is to give richness body a

smooth mouthfeel all that good stuff except in 
Thai cuisine we use zero dairy at all nothing

in any form whatsoever so coconut milk does that 
job coconut milk comes in many many forms which

one to use right you got can you got this you 
got powdered you got frozen they'd be I've seen

lots of different types let me preface you is 
that with this up when I was little one of my

tasks in the kitchen was to make coconut milk 
and that sounds cool and everything but it was

tedious it was a long time consuming process and 
on the one hand I'm glad I don't have to do that

anymore but on the other hand it's really hard to 
match the quality of a freshly made coconut milk

in my experience this comes the closest to a fresh 
coconut milk this is 100% coconut milk and that's

what you want the canned stuff is fine for the 
most part but they usually contain preservatives

additives thickeners emulsifiers it's thicker 
than regular coke than fresh coconut milk and

the flavor is no longer similar to a freshly 
made coconut milk so I always prefer this one

having said that I haven't tried all the brands 
so I can't say but from what I've tried another

reason why can coconuts don't work so well in 
Thai cuisine sometimes is when we make curries

we want to separate it want to cook the coconuts 
so long that the fat breaks away from the coconut

coconut milk but they it seems like they have 
homogenized is to stabilize the fat and that

doesn't happen frustrated me a lot when I tried 
to make curries and I didn't know that and I use

this and if the coconut milk was not separating 
for me so that's that if you have cans sitting at

home don't throw it out use it anyway I'm just 
saying that that's the one that I prefer other

than that I've also got curry paste curry paste 
comes in many different brands many different

forms most of you are probably familiar with 
about five major ones red yellow green Penang

and Massimo these are some familiar names right 
in reality there are hundreds of different kinds

in fact curry paste is essentially indefinite 
as well because technically you can make your

own and make your own proprietary signature blend 
and you know make it however you want if you're

the kind of person who love making things from 
scratch I have a tutorial video on how to make

it with a mortar and pestle old-school and it's 
a great experience but it does require time and

love and commitment and if you don't have one of 
those these work just fine I've had really good

experience with these they don't usually contain 
any additives it's just straight-up paste of herbs

and spices the only you need to worry about its 
different brands have different levels of spice

so your spice tolerance is not very high Matt 
Lloyd brand I think is generally milder than

some other brands that I've tried so those are 
ingredients so that's all I'm going to talk about

right now and what I'm going to move on next is 
to talk about the structure of some of the dishes
